Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Grant Application for ASPLOS 2015

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project funds travel support to enable students to defray the costs of traveling to and attending ASPLOS-2015. The conference is being held in Istanbul, Turkey. ASPLOS is the premier forum for multidisciplinary systems research spanning computer architecture and hardware, programming languages and compilers, operating systems and networking, as well as applications and user interfaces. The research may target diverse goals such as performance, energy and thermal efficiency, resiliency, security, and sustainability. The importance of such cross-cutting research continues to grow as we grapple with the end of Dennard scaling, the explosion of big data, scales ranging from ultra-low power wearable devices to exascale parallel and cloud computers, the need for sustainability, and increasingly human-centered applications.

The funding provided to students will enable much broader participation by students, especially by those are US citizens and permanent residents of US and may otherwise not have adequate support at their educational institution. Underrepresented minorities will be encouraged to apply. Students will be able to attend all events associated with the conference and a rich set of workshops and tutorials. Student interactions and mentoring are vital for the growth of the computer systems research community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Conference on Architecture Support for Programming Languages and Operating Systems (ASPLOS) is a premier forum for multidisciplinary systems research spanning computer architecture and hardware, programming languages and compilers, operating systems and networking, as well as applications and userinterfaces.

The purpose of this grant was to support student travel to attend the ASPLOS conference.  Such travel enriches the conference, exposes students to the latest scientific findings in the field, and helps educate the next generation of scholars and practitioners in the field.  It also provides support for under-served groups to attend the conference.

Approximately 54 students from around the world applied for a student travelgrant to ASPLOS.  The total sponsorship totalled $45000 with $20000 coming fromthe NSF.  All eligible students were provided some support to attend theconference.  On average, students received approximately $1000 to defray their travel expenses.


The award from the National Science Foundation supported the partial travel costs of 15 US based students.   Among these students, more than 25% are women.The average amount awarded per student using this NSF grant was $1227.  

The US based students supported by this grant will likely seek employment at US corporations, universities, and government research labs. Hence, the travel awards made possible by this grant helps contribute to the creation and retention of a highly trained, diverse, and capable IT work force which is critical for continued economic growth.
